transcript.speaker: Ana Silva
transcript.text: Welcome everyone to our Innovation Workshop focused on youth-led climate solutions. Today we'll explore how young innovators are tackling environmental challenges.

transcript.speaker: David Kim
transcript.text: Climate technology is advancing rapidly, but we need more young voices in the conversation. The funding gap for climate startups is still significant - about 2 billion euros globally.

transcript.speaker: Sofia Patel
transcript.text: As a young entrepreneur, I can confirm that funding is our biggest barrier. My renewable energy project needs 200K euros to reach the next milestone, but traditional investors don't understand our vision.

transcript.speaker: Miguel Torres
transcript.text: That's where programs like YSI become crucial. We need to create ecosystems that support young innovators not just with money, but with mentorship and recognition.

transcript.speaker: Ana Silva
transcript.text: Let's dive deeper into the three pillars: Capital, Recognition, and Wellbeing. Sofia, how has the lack of capital affected your project timeline?

transcript.speaker: Sofia Patel
transcript.text: Without proper funding, I've had to bootstrap everything. My wellbeing has suffered - working 80-hour weeks isn't sustainable. Recognition would help attract investors.

transcript.speaker: David Kim
transcript.text: This highlights the interconnected nature of the three pillars. Success requires all three working together - capital enables innovation, recognition attracts more capital, and wellbeing ensures sustainable growth.

transcript.speaker: Miguel Torres
transcript.text: For the action items, I suggest we create a climate-focused track within YSI, with dedicated funding and mentorship for environmental solutions.

transcript.speaker: Ana Silva
transcript.text: Excellent idea. Let's also establish partnerships with climate VCs and organize a specific showcase for environmental innovations.
